text.value: Traceback (most recent call last): File "C:\sandbox\python\100-days-of-code-Python\Day_045\main.py", line 4, in <module> soup = BeautifulSoup(file, "html.parser") ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ File "C:\sandbox\python\100-days-of-code-Python\venv\Lib\site-packages\bs4\__init__.py", line 314, in __init__ markup = markup.read() ^^^^^^^^^^^^^ File "C:\Users\simon\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python312\Lib\encodings\cp1252.py", line 23, in decode return codecs.charmap_decode(input,self.errors,decoding_table)[0] ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ UnicodeDecodeError: 'charmap' codec can't decode byte 0x9d in position 281: character maps to <undefined>

This error is occurring because the file you are trying to parse with BeautifulSoup is not properly encoded. The error message indicates that the file contains a byte `0x9d` at position 281, which cannot be decoded using the `cp1252` encoding (which is the default encoding used by Python on Windows systems).
To resolve this issue, you need to ensure that the file is properly encoded, preferably in UTF-8 format. If the file is not in UTF-8 format, you can try to decode it using the appropriate encoding by passing the `from_encoding` parameter to the `BeautifulSoup` constructor.
Here's an example of how you can do that:
```python from bs4 import BeautifulSoup
with open("file.html", "rb") as file: content = file.read()
soup = BeautifulSoup(content, "html.parser", from_encoding="latin-1") ```
In this example, we're opening the file in binary mode (`"rb"`) to read the raw bytes, and then passing those bytes to `BeautifulSoup` along with the `from_encoding` parameter set to `"latin-1"` (which is a common encoding for Western European languages).
If you're unsure of the encoding used in the file, you can try different encodings until you find one that works, or use a library like `chardet` to automatically detect the encoding.
```python import chardet
with open("file.html", "rb") as file: content = file.read()
detected_encoding = chardet.detect(content)["encoding"] soup = BeautifulSoup(content, "html.parser", from_encoding=detected_encoding) ```
By properly handling the encoding of the file, you should be able to parse it successfully with BeautifulSoup.
